Jinnō Shōtōki, pp. 148-150. ==Events of the Enryaku era== * 782 (Enryaku 1, 6th month): Fujiwara no Uona was removed from his office.Nussbaum, "Fujiwara no Uona" at p. 211. * 783 (Enryaku 3, in the 3rd month): Fujiwara no Tamaro died at the age of 62 years.Titsingh, p.86; Brown, p. 278. * 783 (Enryaku 3, in the 7th month): Fujiwara no KorekimiImperial Japanese Commission to the World's Columbian Exposition. (1893). History of the Empire of Japan, p. 106. was promoted in the hierarchy of the Imperial court. * 784 (Enryaku 3): The emperor moves the capital to NagaokaNussbaum, "Nagaoka-kyō" at p. 682. * 788 (Enryaku 7): The Buddhist monk SaichōNussbaum, "Saichō" at p. 805. establishes a monastery on Mt Hiei * 793 (Enryaku 12): Construction began on the Buddhist temple complex at Enryaku-ji.Brown, p. 279. * 17 December 794 (Enryaku 13, 21st day of the 10th month): The Emperor moved by carriage in a grand parade from Nara to Heian-kyō. * 796 (Enryaku 15): Copper coins were minted with the legend Ren-hei Ei-hō.Appert, Georges.
